      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-138415-_zdjjbbl29xlf"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>This article reviews a cluster of malicious activity that we identify as CL-STA-0049. Since at least March 2023, a suspected Chinese threat actor has targeted governments, defense, telecommunication, education and aviation sectors in Southeast Asia and South America.</p>
<p>The observed activity includes collecting sensitive information from compromised organizations, as well as obtaining information about high-ranking officials and individuals at those organizations.</p>
<p>During our investigation, we were able to shed new light on the attacker’s tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs), including the attack flow, entry vector via web shells and covert communication channels.</p>
<p>The threat actor behind this <a href="https://www.elastic.co/security-labs/fragile-web-ref7707" target="_blank" rel="noopener">activity cluster</a> used a recently discovered sophisticated backdoor we named Squidoor (aka <a href="https://www.elastic.co/security-labs/finaldraft" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FinalDraft</a>), which targets both Windows and Linux systems. This article reveals a new Windows variant of Squidoor, and provides a deeper understanding of Squidoor's command and control server (C2) communication than has been previously described.</p>
<p>Squidoor is an advanced backdoor that supports multiple modules, designed for stealth. It features a rarely seen set of capabilities, including using multiple protocols to communicate with the C2 such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Outlook API</li>
<li>Domain Name System (DNS) tunneling</li>
<li>Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) tunneling</li>
</ul>
<p>Based on our analysis of the TTPs, we assess with moderate-high confidence that this activity originates in China.</p>
<p>Our objective in sharing this analysis is to equip cybersecurity professionals in these high-risk sectors with effective detection and mitigation strategies against these advanced threats.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed in this article through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/infographics/xsiam-product-tour?utm_source=google-jg-amer-cortex-socf-siam&amp;utm_medium=paid_search&amp;utm_campaign=google-cortex-xsiam-amer-multi-awareness-en-eg-non_brand-broad&amp;utm_content=7014u000001eDtMAAU&amp;utm_term=siem%20integration&amp;cq_plac=&amp;cq_net=g&amp;gad_source=1&amp;gclid=EAIaIQobChMI9sLv--faiAMVVnFHAR1IcyvDEAAYASAAEgJ8VPD_BwE" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/security-subscriptions" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a> for the <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/next-generation-firewall" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a>, including:
<ul>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a></li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a></li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/backdoor/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Backdoor</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/lolbas/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LOLBAS</a></strong>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/china/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">China</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-138415-_vkgsyumtc94y"></a>Initial Access to Networks: Deploying Multiple Web Shells</h2>
<p>To gain access to networks, the threat actor behind CL-STA-0049 primarily attempted to exploit various vulnerabilities in Internet Information Services (IIS) servers. They followed this initial compromise with the deployment of multiple web shells on infected servers. These web shells served as persistent backdoors, allowing the threat actor to maintain access and execute commands on compromised systems.</p>
<p>Our research identified four primary web shells used in the attack:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">OutlookDC.aspx</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Error.aspx (1)</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Error.aspx (2)</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">TimeoutAPI.aspx</span></li>
</ul>
<p>The deployed web shells exhibited significant similarities, indicating a common origin. The shared characteristics include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Embedded decryption keys of the same length (and sometimes shared among different samples)</li>
<li>Extensive obfuscation using junk code (shown in Figure 1 below)</li>
<li>Consistent string patterns and code structures</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 1 shows a code snippet of one of the web shells.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138418" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138418" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138418 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-723751-138415-1.png" alt="Screen showing multiple lines of the web shell's code, displayed in a text editor with syntax highlighting." width="1000" height="350" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-723751-138415-1.png 1139w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-723751-138415-1-786x275.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-723751-138415-1-768x269.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138418" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. Code snippet of a web shell used in the attack.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The threat actor stored some of the web shells on <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">bashupload[.]com</span> and downloaded and decoded them using <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/certutil" target="_blank" rel="noopener">certutil</a>, as shown in the command-line string in Figure 2. Bashupload is a web application that enables users to upload files using the command line and download them to another server.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138420" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138420" style="width: 780px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138420 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-727375-138415-2.png" alt="Code snippet of Certutil, three lines total. " width="780" height="80" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-727375-138415-2.png 780w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-727375-138415-2-768x79.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 780px) 100vw, 780px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138420" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Certutil is used to retrieve web shells from bashupload.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_x3xxts17kkik"></a>Lateral Movement Within Compromised Endpoints: Spreading Web Shells</h3>
<p>We observed that the threat actor attempted to spread the web shells across different servers. To do that, it used <a href="https://curl.se/">curl</a> and <a href="https://github.com/fortra/impacket?tab=readme-ov-file#impacket" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Impacket</a>, as shown in Figure 3 below. The threat actor also tried to conceal one of the web shells as a certificate and copy it to other servers using <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/wmisdk/wmi-start-page" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI)</a>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138422" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138422" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138422 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3.png" alt="Diagram showing a cyber attack process involving multiple steps in Cortex XDR such as downloading files from Microsoft Exchange, copying and executing commands, and uploading a web shell to a website, with various commands and URLs illustrated." width="1000" height="530" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3.png 1803w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3-786x417.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3-1320x700.png 1320w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3-768x407.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-729889-138415-3-1536x814.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138422" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Cortex alert data showing attempts to download and copy web shells to remote machines.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-138415-_cvorsastdvtm"></a>Squidoor: A Modular Stealthy Backdoor</h2>
<p>We call the main backdoor the attackers used Squidoor. (Elastic Security Labs recently published <a href="https://www.elastic.co/security-labs/fragile-web-ref7707" target="_blank" rel="noopener">similar research</a> on this activity cluster, referring to the backdoor as <a href="https://www.elastic.co/security-labs/finaldraft" target="_blank" rel="noopener">FinalDraft</a>.) Squidoor is a sophisticated backdoor that was built for stealth, allowing it to operate in highly monitored and secured networks.</p>
<p>The threat actors primarily used this backdoor to:</p>
<ul>
<li>Maintain access</li>
<li>Move laterally</li>
<li>Create stealthy communication channels with its operators</li>
<li>Collect sensitive information about the targeted organizations</li>
</ul>
<p>During our investigation, we discovered that Squidoor was in fact multi-platform malware, with versions for both Windows and Linux operating systems.</p>
<p>Squidoor offers a range of different protocols and methods operators can use to configure the malware to communicate with its C2 server. The Windows version of Squidoor grants the attackers 10 different methods for C2 communication, and the Linux version allows nine.</p>
<p>Some communication methods are meant for external communication with the C2, while other methods are for internal communication between Squidoor implants within a compromised network. This variety of communication methods enables the attackers to adjust to different scenarios and stay under the radar.</p>
<p>Squidoor can receive the following commands:</p>
<ul>
<li>Collect information about the infected machine</li>
<li>Execute arbitrary commands</li>
<li>Inject payloads into selected processes</li>
<li>Deliver additional payloads</li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 4 shows a diagram of the communication paths in a network infected with Squidoor, illustrating how threat operators configured most of the implants to only communicate internally to remain undetected.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138424" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138424" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138424 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4.png" alt="Diagram showing various cybersecurity threats targeting different platforms including Outlook, Email, Browser, and more each illustrated with connected icons representing security and databases." width="1000" height="425" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4-786x334.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4-1646x700.png 1646w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4-768x327.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-733977-138415-4-1536x653.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138424" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Example of communication paths for implants in a network infected with Squidoor.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_uh8uz3ra1m6v"></a>Using a Rarely Observed LOLBAS Technique: Cdb.exe</h3>
<p>To execute Squidoor, the threat actor abused the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/debugger/debugging-a-user-mode-process-using-cdb" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft Console Debugger</a> binary named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdb.exe</span>. Attackers delivered <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdb.exe</span> to the infected environments, saved it to disk as <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">C:\ProgramData\fontdrvhost.exe</span> and used it to load and execute shellcode in memory. While using <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdb.exe</span> is a known <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">living-off-the-land-binaries-and-scripts</span> (<a href="https://lolbas-project.github.io/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">LOLBAS</a>) technique, its use is <a href="https://car.mitre.org/analytics/CAR-2020-05-003/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">quite rare</a> and has only been reported a handful of times.</p>
<p>Upon execution, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cdb.exe</span> (renamed by the attacker to <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fontdrvhost.exe</span>) loaded the shellcode from a file named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">config.ini</span>.</p>
<p>After the first execution, we observed the attackers using one of Squidoor’s payloads (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">LoadShellcode.x64.dll</span>, loaded into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span>) to load and decrypt another Squidoor implant from a file on disk named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">wmsetup.log</span>. Figure 5 illustrates these two flows of execution.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138426" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138426" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138426 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5.png" alt="Text displaying command line instructions to schedule tasks and configure settings on a Microsoft Windows operating system." width="1000" height="429" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5-786x337.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5-1633x700.png 1633w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5-768x329.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-738249-138415-5-1536x659.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138426" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. The execution flow of loading Squidoor.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Squidoor’s persistence was achieved using a scheduled task named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Microsoft\Windows\AppID\EPolicyManager</span>. This task executed the shellcode. Figure 6 shows the command to create the scheduled task to keep Squidoor persistent.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138428" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138428" style="width: 780px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138428 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-741646-138415-6.png" alt="Diagram illustrating the loading process of the Squiddor backdoor involving two sequences of executable file interactions with system files, highlighting steps from reading config files to executing a DLL." width="780" height="109" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-741646-138415-6.png 780w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-741646-138415-6-768x107.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 780px) 100vw, 780px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138428" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Command to create a scheduled task to maintain Squidoor persistence on an affected Windows host.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_2ouqc4wn5f6x"></a>Squidoor Execution Flow</h3>
<p>Once Squidoor was loaded into memory, it executed its exported function named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">UpdateTask</span>. Squidoor’s execution flow begins with decrypting its hard-coded configuration.</p>
<p>The configuration of Squidoor contains a single digit (0-9) corresponding to a <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-language/switch-statement-c" target="_blank" rel="noopener">switch case</a> that determines which communication method it will use. There are other configuration fields that might not be used, depending on the variant of the malware. These fields include values needed for the communication with the C2 server, which will vary depending on which communication method it uses.</p>
<p>These values can include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Domains</li>
<li>IP addresses</li>
<li>Listening ports</li>
<li>Encryption key</li>
<li>Access token</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_mmaonuuseup6"></a>Communication Methods</h3>
<p>The Windows version of Squidoor supports 10 different methods for C2 communication. Table 1 breaks out these 10 different methods based on their corresponding switch case digits.</p>
<table style="width: 100%; height: 744px;">
<tbody>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px; text-align: center; width: 12.0925%;"><b>Switch Case Digit</b></td>
<td style="height: 80px; text-align: center; width: 26.0794%;"><b>Internal Class Name</b></td>
<td style="height: 80px; text-align: center; width: 60.7766%;"><b>Description</b></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="height: 56px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">0</span></td>
<td style="height: 56px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CHttpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 56px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">HTTP-based communication</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 56px;">
<td style="height: 56px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span></td>
<td style="height: 56px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CReverseTcpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 56px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Reverse TCP connection to a remote server</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="height: 57px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CReverseUdpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Reverse UDP connection to a remote server</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CBindTcpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Listen for incoming TCP connections (suspected to be used for only internal communication)</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="height: 57px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">4</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CBindHttpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Listen for incoming HTTP connections (become an HTTP Server)</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 81px;">
<td style="height: 81px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5</span></td>
<td style="height: 81px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">COutLookTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 81px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Communicate via an Outlook mail API  </span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="height: 57px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CIcmpTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Utilize ICMP tunneling for communication</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 57px;">
<td style="height: 57px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CDnsTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 57px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Utilize DNS tunneling for communication</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 83px;">
<td style="height: 83px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8</span></td>
<td style="height: 83px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">CWebTransChannel</span></span></p>
<p>&nbsp;</td>
<td style="height: 83px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Communicate via a mail client retrieved from the configuration file</span></td>
</tr>
<tr style="height: 80px;">
<td style="height: 80px; width: 12.0925%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px; width: 26.0794%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CBindSMBTransChannel</span></td>
<td style="height: 80px; width: 60.7766%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Use named pipes for communication (only internal communication, and only on the Windows version)</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 1. Switch-case values for Squidoor C2 communication methods.</span></p>
<p>These communication methods have distinct names in the malware’s code, as shown in Figure 7.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138430" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138430" style="width: 450px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138430 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-744140-138415-7.png" alt="A screenshot of code, featuring various programming functions and mode settings. The code includes syntax and parameters related to configurations and values. Several sections are highlighted in red boxes. " width="450" height="632" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-744140-138415-7.png 528w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-744140-138415-7-313x440.png 313w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-744140-138415-7-498x700.png 498w" sizes="(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138430" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Code snippets of Squidoor’s communication methods grouped by switch case.</figcaption></figure>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_stltu5r6c5h"></a>Outlook Transport Channel Analysis</h3>
<p>This section examines the Outlook mail client communication method. Figure 8 shows the flow of this method.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138446" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138446" style="width: 786px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="size-medium wp-image-138446 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/Squidoor-F8-786x375.png" alt="Flowchart illustrating an email query process involving Microsoft Outlook, with steps including API querying, drafting emails, content retrieval, sending, and querying operations, linked with decision points based on found or not found statuses." width="786" height="375" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/Squidoor-F8-786x375.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/Squidoor-F8-768x366.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/Squidoor-F8.png 1000w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138446" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Flow of the communication mechanism via Outlook API for Squidoor.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When executed with the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">COutLookTransChannel</span> configuration, Squidoor will first log in to the <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Microsoft identity platform</a> using a hard-coded <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity-platform/refresh-tokens" target="_blank" rel="noopener">refresh token</a> as shown in Figure 9. The Microsoft Graph API token is stored in the following registry keys, based on the user’s privileges:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\UUID\&lt;uuid_stored_in_configuration&gt;</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\UUID\&lt;uuid_stored_in_configuration&gt;</span></li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_138432" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138432" style="width: 800px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138432 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9.png" alt="Screenshot of a network request showing HTTP headers with URLs related to Microsoft Graph API. The text includes technical details like content type, user agent, and length of the content. Some of the information is redacted. " width="800" height="188" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9.png 1970w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9-786x184.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9-1920x450.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9-768x180.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-749077-138415-9-1536x360.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138432" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. HTTP POST request by Squidoor for logging in to the Microsoft identity platform.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Next, Squidoor sends an HTTP GET request to a specific Pastebin page that is hard coded in its configuration. The Pastebin page is named <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Local365</span>, and only contains the number <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1</span>. We suspect the attackers monitor these GET requests to Pastebin as a method to track how many implants have connected via the Outlook API.</p>
<p>Next, Squidoor uses the Outlook REST API to query the drafts folder, searching for mails with a subject containing the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">p_{random_generated_number}</span>. If it finds no such mail, Squidoor will send an email to the attackers with the aforementioned generated string as the subject, including a Base64-encoded random sequence of bytes in the content. Figure 10 shows an HTTP POST request of this C2 traffic.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138434" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138434" style="width: 919px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138434 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-753110-138415-10.png" alt="Screenshot of HTTP headers displayed in a network analysis tool, with User-Agent and other header information visible, sent to graph.microsoft.com, containing obscured sensitive data in the request body." width="919" height="160" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-753110-138415-10.png 919w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-753110-138415-10-786x137.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-753110-138415-10-768x134.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 919px) 100vw, 919px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138434" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. HTTP POST request for an email uploaded to the attackers’ Outlook account by Squidoor.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The attackers use the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">{random_generated_number}</span> identifier to differentiate between different Squidoor implants that query commands from the same Outlook mail inbox.</p>
<p>After sending the initial beacon, Squidoor starts to query the email account for commands. To do so, it queries the drafts folder for mails containing the string <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">r_{random_generated_number}</span> in the subject with a preceding <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">r</span> instead of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">p</span> with the same generated number value as before. Figure 11 shows an example of such a query sent by Squidoor.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138436" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138436" style="width: 700px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138436 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-755842-138415-11.png" alt="Screenshot of a Squidoor query." width="700" height="49" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-755842-138415-11.png 868w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-755842-138415-11-786x55.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-755842-138415-11-768x54.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138436" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 11. A query Squidoor uses to retrieve emails containing commands to execute.</figcaption></figure>
<p>If such an email exists, Squidoor will retrieve its contents and delete it from the attacker's mailbox. Next, the contents of the retrieved message go through several stages of deobfuscation and decoding. This mechanism allows the malware to receive commands or additional malicious code from its C2 server disguised as innocent-looking Outlook network traffic.</p>
<h4><a id="post-138415-_xj8psyup6lew"></a>Decoding the Email Content</h4>
<p>The decoding mechanism of the content of the mails is as follows:</p>
<ol>
<li>Transform the email to bytes by using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CryptStringToBinaryA</span> WinAPI</li>
<li>Decode from Base64 encoding</li>
<li>Decode the content via a combination of AES and a custom XOR decryption algorithm</li>
<li>Decompress the decoded content using <a href="https://www.zlib.net/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">zlib</a> 1.2.12</li>
</ol>
<p>The decompressed content tells Squidoor which command it should execute, along with any additional relevant data for execution, such as additional payloads or file paths.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_85z8kz246q17"></a>Squidoor’s Main Capabilities</h3>
<p>Squidoor has a list of commands it can receive from the C2 server, which grants the attacker a variety of different capabilities to gain full control over the infected machine. These capabilities include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Host reconnaissance and fingerprinting, including:
<ul>
<li>Username and privileges</li>
<li>Hostname</li>
<li>IP address</li>
<li>Operating system (OS) type</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Executing arbitrary commands</li>
<li>Querying files and directories</li>
<li>Querying running processes</li>
<li>Exfiltrating files</li>
<li>Deploying additional malware</li>
<li>Injecting payloads into additional processes</li>
<li>Sending commands to other Squidoor implants via TCP</li>
<li>Sending commands to other Squidoor implants via named pipes (Windows variant only)</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_k02mg1r20t2u"></a>Squidoor Code Injection</h3>
<p>Squidoor can receive a command from the C2 instructing the malware to perform code injection into an additional process. Squidoor injects a payload using <a href="https://www.ired.team/offensive-security/code-injection-process-injection/dll-injection" target="_blank" rel="noopener">classic DLL injection</a>, calling the following Windows API functions <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://ntdoc.m417z.com/rtlcreateuserthread" target="_blank" rel="noopener">RtlCreateUserThread</a></span>, <a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/memoryapi/nf-memoryapi-virtualallocex" target="_blank" rel="noopener">​​<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">VirtualAllocEx</span></a> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"><a href="https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/memoryapi/nf-memoryapi-writeprocessmemory" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WriteProcessMemory</a></span>.</p>
<p>On the Windows version, depending on the command the attackers sent, Squidoor will determine which process it will use for injection. The two options available for the attacker are:</p>
<ul>
<li>Attempting to inject code into <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span>
<ul>
<li>If <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span> does not exist in <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">system32</span> (as is the case in Windows 11), it injects <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">conhost.exe</span> instead</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Performing an injection into an already running process on the system determined by a process ID (PID) selected by the attacker</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_4stn80871d1z"></a>Modular Backdoor</h3>
<p>During our investigation, we observed Squidoor executing additional modules that it injected into other Windows OS processes, such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">conhost.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">taskhostw.exe</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">vmtoolsd.exe</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Figure 12 shows how, in one instance, the threat actor delivered payloads (modules) that they injected into multiple instances of <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span>. The threat actor used these injected modules to move laterally using Windows Remote Management (WinRM), steal data and execute commands on remote endpoints. The modules require a password as an argument to run, to evade dynamic analysis and sandboxes.</p>
<p>The observed passwords included:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">t0K1p092</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">PeN17PFS50</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sElf98RqkF</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Aslire597</span></li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_138438" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138438" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138438 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12.png" alt="Cortex XDR diagram illustrating the cyber attack process involving initial access through a vulnerable host, followed by various stages of system exploitation and reconnaissance." width="1000" height="614" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12.png 1930w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12-717x440.png 717w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12-1140x700.png 1140w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12-768x472.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-758401-138415-12-1536x943.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138438" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 12. Squidoor injects multiple payloads into different <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span> instances.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">mspaint.exe</span> injected payloads were not written to the disk and were executed in system memory. From the behavioral pattern, these payloads appear to support a number of command-line arguments to perform multiple actions such as the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Uploading or deleting files remotely</li>
<li>Executing PowerShell scripts without invoking the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">powershell.exe</span> binary</li>
<li>Executing arbitrary commands</li>
<li>Stealing specific files</li>
<li>Performing <a href="https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1550/002/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">pass the hash</a> attacks</li>
<li>Enumerating specific user accounts</li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-138415-_ewvfil2cbchi"></a>Abusing Pastebin to Store Configuration Data</h2>
<p>As we previously mentioned, on some of its communication modes, Squidoor will send an HTTP GET request to Pastebin.</p>
<p>We found two Pastebin accounts operated by the attackers and the aliases they created for themselves.</p>
<p>One of the accounts has been operational for almost a year, with the attacker adding new content occasionally.</p>
<p>The threat actor apparently used these Pastebin accounts to store components related to the different communication methods of the malware such as access tokens and API keys as shown in Figure 13 below.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138440" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138440" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138440 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-762547-138415-13.png" alt="Screenshot of the Pastebin website showing a list of text uploads, with varying uploaded dates, expiration statuses, number of hits, comments, and syntax used. Some information is redacted. " width="1000" height="628" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-762547-138415-13.png 1290w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-762547-138415-13-701x440.png 701w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-762547-138415-13-1115x700.png 1115w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-762547-138415-13-768x482.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138440" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 13. Example of a Pastebin account controlled by the attackers.</figcaption></figure>
<p>At the beginning of February 2025, the attackers deleted all the files shown in Figure 13 above, and added several new ones, shown in Figure 14. Those files contain different Microsoft Graph API tokens and the titles suggest different target names.</p>
<figure id="attachment_138442" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-138442" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-138442 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-765720-138415-14.png" alt="Screenshot of the Pastebin website showing a list of text uploads, with varying uploaded dates, expiration statuses, number of hits, comments, and syntax used. Some information is redacted. " width="1000" height="487" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-765720-138415-14.png 1133w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-765720-138415-14-786x383.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/02/word-image-765720-138415-14-768x374.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-138442" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 14. Updated Pastebin page controlled by the attackers.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In addition, we suspect attackers used these accounts to track the number of Squidoor implants executed around the world, by tracing the number of implants that queried Pastebin.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138415-_xt9fxuxpqz5t"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>The threat actor behind the CL-STA-0049 cluster of activity has attacked high-value targets in South America and Southeast Asia. The primary objective appears to be gaining a foothold and obtaining sensitive information from their targets. We assess with moderate-high confidence that this threat actor is of Chinese origin.</p>
<p>Squidoor, the main backdoor used in this operation, is engineered for an enhanced level of stealth and offers 10 distinct methods for covert C2 communication. This versatility has allowed the attackers to adapt to various scenarios and minimize suspicious network traffic emanating from compromised environments.</p>
<p>Squidoor's multi-platform implementations, with tailored versions for both Windows and Linux operating systems, expand its reach and attack surface. This adaptability enables the malware to infiltrate diverse network ecosystems, potentially compromising a broader range of targets and complicating detection and mitigation efforts across heterogeneous infrastructures.</p>
<p>We encourage security practitioners and defenders to study this report and use the information provided to enhance current detection, prevention and hunting practices to strengthen their security posture.</p>
<h3><a id="post-138415-_z5usflbfd2th"></a>Protections and Mitigations</h3>
<p>For Palo Alto Networks customers, our products and services provide the following coverage associated with this activity cluster:</p>
<ul>
<li>The <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the IoCs shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/advanced-url-filtering" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> identifies domains associated with this group as malicious.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/ngfw" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Next-Generation Firewall</a> with the <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-threat-prevention/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced Threat Prevention</a> security subscription can help block the attacks with best practices. Advanced Threat Prevention has inbuilt machine learning-based detection that can detect exploits in real time.</li>
<li><a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/cortex/cortex-xdr" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> are designed to:
<ul>
<li>Prevent the execution of known malicious malware and also prevent the execution of unknown malware using <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/products/secure-the-network/subscriptions/threat-prevention" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Behavioral Threat Protection</a> and machine learning based on the Local Analysis module.</li>
<li>Protect against exploitation of different vulnerabilities using the <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Endpoint-Protection-Capabilities" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anti-Exploitation modules</a> as well as Behavioral Threat Protection.</li>
<li>Detect post-exploit activity, including <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/resources/techbriefs/cortex-xdr-identity-analytics" target="_blank" rel="noopener">credential-based attacks</a>, with behavioral <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-Pro-Administrator-Guide/Analytics-Concepts" target="_blank" rel="noopener">analytics</a> through Cortex XDR Pro and XSIAM.</li>
<li>Detect user and credential-based threats by analyzing anomalous user activity from multiple data sources.</li>
<li>Protect from threat actors dropping and executing commands from web shells using Anti-Webshell Protection.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been impacted or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">UK: +44.20.3743.3660</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Asia: +65.6983.8730</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">India: 00080005045107</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings, including file samples and indicators of compromise, with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>
<h2><a id="post-138415-_ydqdbjg0dngh"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h2>
<p>SHA256 hash for Squidoor - Windows version (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">config.ini</span>)</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f663149d618be90e5596b28103d38e963c44a69a5de4a1be62547259ca9ffd2d</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SHA256 hashes for Squidoor - Linux version</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">83406905710e52f6af35b4b3c27549a12c28a628c492429d3a411fdb2d28cc8c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">8187240dafbc62f2affd70da94295035c4179c8e3831cb96bdd9bd322e22d029</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">fa2a6dbc83fe55df848dfcaaf3163f8aaefe0c9727b3ead1da6b9fa78b598f2b</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">3fcfc4cb94d133563b17efe03f013e645fa2f878576282805ff5e58b907d2381</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">f45661ea4959a944ca2917454d1314546cc0c88537479e00550eef05bed5b1b9</span></li>
</ul>
<p>SHA256 hashes for associated web shells</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">9f62c1d330dddad347a207a6a565ae07192377f622fa7d74af80705d800c6096</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">461f5969b8f2196c630f0868c2ac717b11b1c51bc5b44b87f5aad19e001869cc</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">224becf3f19a3f69ca692d83a6fabfd2d78bab10f4480ff6da9716328e8fc727</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">6c1d918b33b1e6dab948064a59e61161e55fccee383e523223213aa2c20c609c</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">81bd2a8d68509dd293a31ddd6d31262247a9bde362c98cf71f86ae702ba90db4</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">7c6d29cb1f3f3e956905016f0171c2450cca8f70546eee56cface7ba31d78970</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">c8a5388e7ff682d3c16ab39e578e6c529f5e23a183cd5cbf094014e0225e2e0a</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">1dd423ff0106b15fd100dbc24c3ae9f9860a1fcdb6a871a1e27576f6681a0850</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">82e68dc50652ab6c7734ee913761d04b37429fca90b7be0711cd33391febff0a</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">e8d6fb67b3fd2a8aa608976bcb93601262d7a95d37f6bae7c0a45b02b3b325ad</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2b6080641239604c625d41857167fea14b6ce47f6d288dc7eb5e88ae848aa57f</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">33689ac745d204a2e5de76bc976c904622508beda9c79f9d64c460ebe934c192</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">5dd361bcc9bd33af26ff28d321ad0f57457e15b4fab6f124f779a01df0ed02d0</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">945313edd0703c966421211078911c4832a0d898f0774f049026fc8c9e7d1865</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">a7d76e0f7eab56618f4671b5462f5c210f3ca813ff266f585bb6a58a85374156</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">265ceb5184cac76477f5bc2a2bf74c39041c29b33a8eb8bd1ab22d92d6bebaf5</span></li>
</ul>
<p>Domains</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Support.vmphere[.]com</span></li>

</ul>

<ul>

                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/macos-malware-targets-crypto-sector/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector">
                    <h4 class="post-title">RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/macos/" title="macOS" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector:macOS">MacOS</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/infostealer/" title="Infostealer" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector:Infostealer">Infostealer</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/contagious-interview/" title="Contagious Interview" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector:Contagious Interview">Contagious Interview</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>
                <div class="card-content__link">
                                    <a class="hyperlink" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/macos-malware-targets-crypto-sector/" title="RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:RustDoor and Koi Stealer for macOS Used by North Korea-Linked Threat Actor to Target the Cryptocurrency Sector:read now">

                    <h4 class="post-title">Bad Likert Judge: A Novel Multi-Turn Technique to Jailbreak LLMs by Misusing Their Evaluation Capability</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/genai/" title="GenAI" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Bad Likert Judge: A Novel Multi-Turn Technique to Jailbreak LLMs by Misusing Their Evaluation Capability:GenAI">GenAI</a>

				</li>

                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of using LLMs to obfuscate malicious JavaScript detection. A man wearing glasses, looking intently at a screen with reflections visible in the glasses of computer code." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/04_Tutorial_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-20T11:00:39+00:00">December 20, 2024</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/using-llms-obfuscate-malicious-javascript/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript">
                    <h4 class="post-title">Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/credential-stealer/" title="credential stealer" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript:credential stealer">Credential stealer</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/data-augmentation/" title="Data Augmentation" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript:Data Augmentation">Data Augmentation</a>
				</li>
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/fraudgpt/" title="FraudGPT" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:Now You See Me, Now You Don’t: Using LLMs to Obfuscate Malicious JavaScript:FraudGPT">FraudGPT</a>
				</li></ul>                </div>

            </div>
                                <div class="pa l-card l-card--slider" >
              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of attackers leveraging Active Directory or LDAP. Close-up view of a server rack panel with illuminated lights and a digital display reading &#039;SYSTEM HACKED&#039;." decoding="async" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/12/02_Vulnerabilities_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>

              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="advanced-backdoor-squidoor:related-resources:LDAP Enumeration: Unveiling the Double-Edged Sword of Active Directory:Threat Research"><span class=""><img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2024-12-17T23:00:43+00:00">December 17, 2024</time></span>

<!--  Start: Footer subscription form -->
<div class="newsletter">
      <div class="l-container">
        <div class="newsletter__wrapper">
          <div class="image__wrapper"> 
            <picture>
			                 <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:400px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-mobile.webp">
			  			                  <source class="lozad" media="(max-width:949px)" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/newsletter-Image-tab.webp">
			  			  			  	<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Revitalized_newsletter-Image-desktop-copy-1.webp" alt="Newsletter">
			              </picture>
          </div>
          <div class="content__wrapper"> 
		    							<span class="pre-title"> 
				<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/palo-alto-logo-small.svg" alt="UNIT 42 Small Logo">
				Get updates from Unit 42			</span>
						           	 <h2>Peace of mind comes from staying ahead of threats. Contact us today.</h2>
			            <form action="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/apps/pan/public/formsubmithandler.submitform.json" method="post" novalidate class="subscribe-form" name="Unit42_Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form">
              <input type="hidden" name="emailFormMask" value="">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formid">
              <input type="hidden" value="531-OCS-018" name="munchkinId">
              <input type="hidden" value="2141" name="lpId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1203" name="programId">
              <input type="hidden" value="1086" name="formVid">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_optinunit42" value="true">
              <input type="hidden" name="mkto_opt-in" value="true">
              <div class="form-group"> 
                <label for="newsletter-email"  id="newsletter-email-label">Your Email</label>
                <input type="emal" placeholder="Your Email" name="Email"  class="subscribe-field" id="newsletter-email" aria-labelledby="newsletter-email-label">
                <p class="error-mail mb-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545"></p>
				<p>Subscribe for email updates to all Unit 42 threat research.<br />By submitting this form, you agree to our <a title="Terms of Use" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/terms-of-use" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Terms of Use">Terms of Use</a> and acknowledge our <a title="Privacy Statement" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/legal-notices/privacy" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="Get updates from Unit 42:Privacy Statement">Privacy Statement.</a></p>
                <div class="g-recaptcha" data-expired-callback="captchaExpires" data-callback="captchaComplete" data-sitekey="6Lc5EhgTAAAAAJa-DzE7EeWABasWg4LKv-R3ao6o"></div>
                <p class="error-recaptcha d-none mt-15 text-danger" style="color: #dc3545">Invalid captcha!</p>
                <button class="l-btn is-disabled" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Get updates from Unit 42:Subscribe" id="unit42footerSubscription_form_button"> 
					Subscribe					<img class="lozad" data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow"  class="arrow">
					<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-loader.svg" alt="loader" class="loader">
			   </button>
				<div class="form-success-message"></div>
              </div>
            </form>
          </div>
        </div>
      </div>
    </div>

<script>

(function($) {
	// Migrated from the unit42-v5 + Modifications
	var subscribeSuccess = false;
	var email = document.getElementById('newsletter-email');
	var subscription_form = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form');
	var subscription_form_button = document.getElementById('unit42footerSubscription_form_button');
	window.captchaComplete = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = true;
		if ($(mail).val() != '' && isEmail($(mail).val())) {
			$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
		}
		setTimeout(function() {
			$(email).focus();
			$('.g-recaptcha iframe').attr('tabindex', '-1');
		}, 100)
	}
	window.captchaExpires = function() {
		subscribeSuccess = false;
		$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
	} 
	$(subscription_form).submit(function(e) {
		e.preventDefault();
		e.stopImmediatePropagation();
		updateEmailMask();
		var success = true;
		var form = $(this);
		var mail = form.find('input[name="Email"]');
		
		if (mail.val() === '') {
			mail.addClass('has-error');
			showError(1);
			success = false;	
		}  else if (!isEmail(mail.val())){
			showError(2);
			success = false;
		}
		else {
			mail.removeClass('has-error');
			$('.error-mail').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (!subscribeSuccess) {
			$('.error-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
		} else {
			$('.error-recaptcha').addClass('d-none');
		}

		if (success && subscribeSuccess) {
			$.ajax({
				type: 'POST',
				url: form.attr('action'),
				data: form.serialize(),
				beforeSend: function() {
                 form.find('button').addClass('is-loading');
    			},
				success: function(msg) {
					form.find('.form-success-message').html('<p class="success-message">You have been successfully subscribed</p>');
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					$(email).val('');
					clearError();
				},
				error: function(jqXHR, textStatus, errorThrown) {
					$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled', true);
					form.find('button').removeClass('is-loading');
					
				}
			});
		}
		return false;
	});
	function showError(error_type){
		if(error_type == 1) {
			$('.error-mail').text("Please enter the email address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		} else if(error_type == 2){
			$('.error-mail').text("Please provide a valid e-mail address.").addClass('error-show');
			$(subscription_form_button).addClass('is-disabled');
		}	
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
	}
	function clearError(){
		$('.error-mail').text("").removeClass('error-show');;
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-loading');
		$(subscription_form_button).removeClass('is-disabled');
	}
	
	$(email).on('input', function (event) { 
		var email = $(this).val();
		if (isEmail(email) ) {			
			clearError();
		} else if(email == ""){
			clearError();
		} else{
			showError(2);			  
		}
    });

	function isEmail(email) {
		var re = /^(([^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+(\.[^<>()\[\]\\.,;:\s@"]+)*)|(".+"))@((\[[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\.[0-9]{1,3}\])|(([a-zA-Z\-0-9]+\.)+[a-zA-Z]{2,}))$/;
		return re.test(String(email).toLowerCase());
	}
	
	var captcha_loaded = false;
         if(!captcha_loaded){
            // recaptcha on foucs call
            $(document).on('change paste keyup', '#newsletter-email', function () {
               if($('.g-recaptcha').hasClass('d-none')){
                $('.g-recaptcha').removeClass('d-none');
               }
               if(!captcha_loaded ){
                  captcha_loaded  = true;
                  // trigger loading api.js (recaptcha.js) script
                  var head = document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
                  var script = document.createElement('script');
                  script.type = 'text/javascript';
                  script.src = 'https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js?hl=en_US';
                  head.appendChild(script);
               }
            });
        }
	
	function updateEmailMask() {
		var email = $("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='Email']").val();
		if (email && email.trim() != '') {
			var maskedEmail = maskEmailAddress(email);
			$("#unit42footerSubscription_form input[name='emailFormMask']").val(maskedEmail);
		}
	}

	function maskEmailAddress (emailAddress) {
		function mask(str) {
			var strLen = str.length;
			if (strLen > 4) {
				return str.substr(0, 1) + str.substr(1, strLen - 1).replace(/\w/g, '*') + str.substr(-1,1);
			}
			return str.replace(/\w/g, '*');
		}
		return emailAddress.replace(/([\w.]+)@([\w.]+)(\.[\w.]+)/g, function (m, p1, p2, p3) {
			return mask(p1) + '@' + mask(p2) + p3;
		});

		return emailAddress;
	}

}(jQuery));
//# sourceMappingURL=main.js.map
	
</script>
<!--  End: Footer subscription form -->

																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/next-gen-casb"   role="link" title="Cloud Access Security Broker" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management:Cloud Access Security Broker">Cloud Access Security Broker</a>
						</li>    
																	<li class="footer-menu-nav__item "> 
							<a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/sase/ztna"   role="link" title="Zero Trust Network Access" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="footer:Products and services:Network Security Platform:CLOUD DELIVERED SECURITY SERVICES:Advanced Threat Prevention:DNS Security:Data Loss Prevention:IoT Security:Next-Generation Firewalls:Hardware Firewalls:Strata Cloud Manager:SECURE ACCESS SERVICE EDGE:Prisma Access:Prisma SD-WAN:Autonomous Digital Experience Management:Cloud Access Security Broker:Zero Trust Network Access">Zero Trust Network Access</a>
						</li>

          </button>
          <button class="modal__minimize-btn is-minimized">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-minimize.svg" alt="Minimize">
          </button>
          <button class="modal__close"> 
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/close-modal.svg" alt="Close button">
          </button>
          <video class="modal__video" id="customVideo">
            <source src="" type="video/mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.
          </video>
          <div class="modal__post-details" tabindex="-1">       
              <h3>Default Heading</h3>
              <a class="l-btn" href="#" title="Right Arrow Icon" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="overview:explore reports:View all reports">Read the article
              <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/right-arrow.svg" alt="Right Arrow">
              </a>
          </div>
          <div class="modal__video-controls">
            <div class="modal__video-seekbar input__wrapper"><span></span>
              <label class="is-hidden" for="modalSeekBar">Seekbar</label>
              <input class="custom-range" id="modalSeekBar" type="range" min="0" max="100" value="1">
              <p class="modal__remaining-time"></p>
            </div>
            <button class="modal__play-btn is-paused" id="playPauseBtn">
            <img class="play" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-play-icon.svg" alt="Play">
            <img class="pause" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/player-pause-icon1.svg" alt="Pause">
          </button>

              <div class="modal__volume__wrapper">

                </button>

                  <label class="is-hidden" for="volumeBar">Volume</label>
                  <input class="volume__bar" id="volumeBar" type="range" min="0" max="1" step="0.1" value="0.7">
                </div>
              </div>
              <button class="modal__minimize-btn" id="minimizeBtn">

    <script type="text/javascript">
	var isProcessing = false; 
    function alter_ul_post_values(obj,post_id,ul_type){
	
		if (isProcessing)    
		return;  
		isProcessing = true;   
		var like_nonce = jQuery('#_wpnonce').val();
		jQuery(obj).find("span").html("..");
                jQuery.ajax({
                    type: "POST",
                    url: "https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/like-dislike-counter-for-posts-pages-and-comments/ajax_counter.php",
                    data: "post_id="+post_id+"&up_type="+ul_type+"&ul_nonce="+like_nonce,
                    success: function(msg){
                            jQuery(obj).find("span").html(msg);
                            isProcessing = false; 
                            jQuery(obj).find('svg').children('path').attr('stroke','#0050FF');
                            jQuery(obj).removeClass('idc_ul_cont_not_liked idc_ul_cont_not_liked_inner');
                    }
 		});
	}
	</script>
    <link rel='stylesheet' id='wpdevart_lightbox_front_end_css-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/lightbox-popup/includes/style/wpdevart_lightbox_front.css?ver=6.7.1' media='all' />
<script src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/js/script.js?ver=1.0.0" id="unit42-v6-navigation-js"></script>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
observer_lozad.observe();

function noSell(event) {
    event.preventDefault();
   if (( typeof OneTrust != 'undefined') &&  (!!OneTrust)) {
       OneTrust.ToggleInfoDisplay();
    }else{
      var href = event.target.getAttribute('href');
        window.open(href, '_blank'); 
    }
}

window.PAN_Clean_Util = {
        isIE: false
};

(function () {
   // INP Util Fix
    function yieldToMain(ms) {
        return new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, ms));
    }
   window.PAN_Clean_Util.yieldToMain = yieldToMain
})();

if(referer == "CloudCortex" || referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
  var Coveo_organizationId = "paloaltonetworksintranet";        
  var techDocsPagePath = "https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/search.html#hd=All%20Prisma%20Cloud%20Documentation&hq=%40panproductcategory%3D%3D(%22Prisma%20Cloud%22)&sort=relevancy&layout=card&numberOfResults=25";
  var languageFromPath="en_US";
  window.Granite = window.Granite || {};
  Granite.I18n = (function() {
  var self = {};
  self.setLocale = function(locale) { };
  self.get = function(text, snippets, note) {
    var out = "";
    if(text){
      if(text ==="coveo.clear"){
        out = "Clear";
      }else if(text ==="coveo.noresultsfound"){
        out = "No results found for this search term.";
      }
    }
    return out;
  };
  return self
  }());
}

  var main_site_critical_top = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTop.min.js';
  var main_site_defered = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/defered.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopBase = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopBase.min.js';
  var main_site_criticalTopProductNav = maindomain_lang+'/etc.clientlibs/panClean/components/mainNavigationComp/clientlibs/panClean/criticalTopProductNav.min.js';
window.PAN_MainNavAsyncUrl = maindomain_lang+"/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html";

function loadScript(url, defer){
    var script1 = document.createElement('script');
    script1.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript');
    script1.setAttribute('src',url);
    if(defer == true){
        script1.setAttribute('defer','defer');
    }
    document.head.appendChild(script1);
}
function loadScript1(url, callback){

    var script = document.createElement("script")
    script.type = "text/javascript";
    if (script.readyState){  //IE
        script.onreadystatechange = function(){
            if (script.readyState == "loaded" || script.readyState == "complete"){
                script.onreadystatechange = null;
                callback();
            }
        };
    } else {  //Others
        script.onload = function(){
            callback();
        };
    }
    script.src = url;
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(script);
}
if(referer == "CloudCortex" || referer == "Prisma" || referer == "Cortex" || referer == "Sase" || referer == "Unit" || referer == "Ngfw"){
	if(referer == "Unit"){
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript(main_site_criticalTopBase, false);
      loadScript1(main_site_criticalTopProductNav, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
	else{
    setTimeout(function(){
      loadScript1(main_site_critical_top, function(){
        window.PAN_initializeProduct2021Nav();
      });
      loadScript(main_site_defered, false);
    }, 3000);
	}
}

$(document).ready(function () {
    setTimeout(function(){
      $('.article-banner .ab__options ul li a').each(function(){
          	$(this).attr('target', "_blank");
      });
    }, 4000);
    
    $( ".do-not-sell-link a" ).on( "click", function( event ) {
        noSell(event);
      });
});
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</body>
</html>
